columns.text: $a)$ Because of its reduced flotation cost, the company cannot actually depend on debt to get funds. An ideal way is to take a weighted average of both equity and debt flotation costs.

$b)$ We have to find out the weighted average of floating cost which we denote with $WF$, where the cost of equity $CE$ is $7\%$, cost of debt $CD$ is $3\%$, equity $E$ is $1$, and the  debt-equity ration $DE$ is $0.75$

$$\begin{align*}
WF &=\biggl(CE \times \frac{E}{1+DE} \bigg) + \biggl(CD \times \frac{DE}{1+DE}\biggl)\\[12pt]
&=\biggl(7\% \times \frac{1}{1+0.75} \bigg) + \biggl(3\% \times \frac{0.75}{1+0.75}\biggl)\\[12pt]
&=\biggl(0.07 \times \frac{1}{1.75} \bigg) + \biggl(0.03 \times \frac{0.75}{1.75}\biggl)\\[12pt]
&=\biggl(0.07 \times 0.571 \bigg) + \biggl(0.03 \times 0.428\biggl)\\[12pt]
&=0.039+0.012\\[7pt]
&=0.051\\[7pt]
&=5.1\%
\end{align*}$$

Therefore, the weighted average of floating cost is $\boxed{5.1\%}$

$c)$, We have to find out the amount been raised which we denote with $AR$, where the weighted average floating cost $WF$ is $5.1\%$ and the new assemble line $NA$ is $\$24,000,000$

$$\begin{align*}
AR&=\frac{NA}{1-WF}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{24,000,000}{1-5.1\%}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{24,000,000}{1-0.051}\\[12pt]
&=\frac{24,000,000}{0.949}\\[12pt]
&=25,289,778.71
\end{align*}$$

So, the amount been raised is $\boxed{\$25,289,778.71}$

Therefore, while all of the money was raised through debt, the ultimate cost of generating this capital for the company will be determined by the debt-equity ratio or capital structure. 

As a consequence, determining the exact amount collected solely through debt will be irrelevant.
